context: The death of Solus, the last male northern white rhino, in 2018 was a pivotal moment, shifting the focus of conservation from protection to resurrection. Scientists have since embarked on an ambitious in-vitro fertilization (IVF) program, harvesting eggs from the last two females, Najin and Fatu. These eggs have been successfully fertilized using cryopreserved sperm from deceased males, resulting in several viable embryos. The next major hurdle involves implanting these embryos into southern white rhino surrogates. This groundbreaking scientific endeavor, while offering a glimmer of hope, is fraught with ethical debates and questions about the genetic viability of a resurrected population.
